questions.stem: Osteoarthritis (OA) in horses is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: An acute infectious arthritis due to bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: A chronic, progressive, noninfectious deterioration of articular cartilage and associated joint structures

options.label: C
options.text: A purely developmental cartilage defect in foals

questions.explanation: OA is a chronic, progressive, noninfectious deterioration of articular cartilage with associated joint changes. It is not primarily infectious (A), purely developmental (C), or a systemic autoimmune disease (D) in horses.

questions.stem: Which joint changes are typically associated with OA?

options.label: B
options.text: Cartilage loss, subchondral bone sclerosis, osteophyte formation, and synovial membrane inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Pure tendon rupture without bone or cartilage changes

questions.explanation: OA features cartilage loss, subchondral bone sclerosis, osteophyte formation, and synovial membrane inflammation. Synovial effusion alone (A), pure tendon rupture (C), or congenital ankylosis (D) do not define OA.

questions.stem: Which horses are most predisposed to OA?

options.label: B
options.text: Athletic horses of all ages and both sexes undergoing repetitive training

questions.explanation: Athletic horses of all ages and both sexes, especially those in repetitive, high-load work, are predisposed, though any horse can develop OA. It is not restricted to geriatric pasture pets (A), foals (C), or stallions (D).

questions.stem: OA commonly develops secondary to which factors?

options.label: A
options.text: Joint instability, trauma, abnormal biomechanical stress, poor joint conformation, repetitive stress, ligament/tendon injuries, infectious arthritis, or osteochondrosis

questions.explanation: OA commonly follows joint instability, trauma, abnormal biomechanical stress, poor conformation, repetitive overuse, prior ligament/tendon/cartilage injury, infectious arthritis, or osteochondrosis. Simple vitamin deficiency (B), laminitis alone (C), or seasonal changes (D) are not the main drivers.

questions.stem: Which pathophysiologic process BEST explains cartilage damage in OA?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammatory mediators (PGE₂, IL-1, TNF-α, MMPs) from synovitis drive matrix degradation and reduce synovial fluid quality

options.label: C
options.text: Pure mechanical wear without any biochemical component

questions.explanation: Synovitis produces mediators like PGE₂, IL‑1, TNF‑α, and MMPs that degrade cartilage matrix and reduce synovial fluid quality, accelerating OA. Direct infection (B) and purely mechanical wear (C) are incomplete explanations.

questions.stem: What changes occur in synovial fluid during OA?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased viscosity and hyaluronic acid concentration

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced viscosity and decreased hyaluronic acid concentration, leading to poor lubrication

options.label: C
options.text: Conversion to pus-filled exudate in all cases

questions.explanation: In OA, synovial fluid becomes less viscous and hyaluronic acid concentration decreases, impairing lubrication and shock absorption. Increased viscosity (A), pus (C), or no change (D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: How does subchondral bone respond in OA?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes softer and more compliant

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes sclerotic and less compliant, transmitting greater forces to cartilage and promoting osteophyte formation

options.label: D
options.text: It liquefies and forms cysts only

questions.explanation: Subchondral bone becomes sclerotic and less compliant, altering load distribution and encouraging osteophyte formation; this further stresses cartilage. It does not soften (A), remain unaffected (C), or simply liquefy (D).

questions.stem: The hallmark lesion of OA is:

options.label: A
options.text: Articular cartilage degeneration, with pain arising from periarticular soft tissues and subchondral bone

options.label: C
options.text: Primary ligament rupture without joint involvement

questions.explanation: The hallmark is articular cartilage degeneration; pain arises from innervated periarticular tissues and subchondral bone rather than cartilage itself. Pure synovial infection (B), ligament rupture (C), or bone tumors (D) describe other conditions.

questions.stem: Which historical finding often suggests OA in a horse?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden onset of neurologic deficits with seizures

options.label: B
options.text: History of intra-articular fracture, osteochondrosis, dislocation, or ligament injury, with insidious lameness in low-motion joints and acute lameness in high-motion joints

questions.explanation: A history of intra-articular injury (fracture, ligament damage, osteochondrosis) plus insidious lameness in low-motion joints or acute lameness in high-motion joints suggests OA. Neurologic signs (A), respiratory disease (C), or skin problems (D) point elsewhere.

questions.stem: Typical physical examination findings in equine OA include:

options.label: B
options.text: Variable lameness, pain on flexion of affected joint(s), synovial effusion (esp. in high-motion joints), reduced range of motion, stiffness after rest, thickened joint capsules, periarticular hardening, and crepitus

questions.explanation: Examination often reveals variable lameness, pain on flexion, synovial effusion (especially in high-motion joints), reduced range of motion, stiffness after rest, joint capsule thickening, periarticular hardening, and crepitus. Colic (A), fever (C), and hindlimb paralysis (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which imaging modality is most commonly used to diagnose OA changes?

options.label: A
options.text: Radiography, showing joint space narrowing, osteophytes, periosteal proliferation, and subchondral sclerosis

questions.explanation: Radiography is the standard imaging tool, revealing joint space narrowing, osteophytes, periosteal bone proliferation, and subchondral sclerosis. CT (B) and other modalities are adjuncts, not first-line.

questions.stem: Which modality offers direct visualization of articular cartilage and subchondral bone lesions?
questions.explanation: Arthroscopy allows direct visualization of cartilage and subchondral bone lesions and can be both diagnostic and therapeutic. MRI and scintigraphy (B, C) detect changes indirectly; “fecal imaging” (D) is facetious.

questions.stem: Main treatment goals in managing OA are to:

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce joint inflammation and pain, restore cartilage homeostasis and mobility, and delay degenerative progression

options.label: D
options.text: Increase joint load to promote bone growth

questions.explanation: OA treatment aims to reduce inflammation and pain, restore or maintain cartilage homeostasis and joint mobility, and delay further degeneration. Eradicating bacteria (A) or increasing load (D) are not relevant goals.

questions.stem: Which nonpharmacologic management strategies are appropriate for OA?

options.label: A
options.text: Rest and controlled exercise, weight management, corrective shoeing, cold therapy, hydrotherapy, physiotherapy, and using soft footing

options.label: B
options.text: Strict prolonged stall rest with no movement

options.label: C
options.text: High-intensity exercise on hard surfaces only

questions.explanation: Appropriate strategies include rest and controlled exercise, weight management, corrective shoeing, cold therapy, hydrotherapy, physiotherapy, and soft footing to reduce joint impact. Prolonged strict rest (B), hard-surface work (C), or unchanged training (D) can worsen outcomes.

questions.stem: Which NSAIDs are commonly used to control pain in equine OA?
questions.explanation: Phenylbutazone and flunixin meglumine are commonly used equine NSAIDs for OA pain control. Human OTC analgesics (B) and sedatives/antivirals (C, D) are not mainstays.

questions.stem: What is the role of intra-articular hyaluronic acid (HA) and PSGAG in OA management?

options.label: A
options.text: HA restores viscosity and lubrication; PSGAG supports cartilage repair and matrix integrity

options.label: D
options.text: They are used only in foals

questions.explanation: HA restores synovial fluid viscosity and lubrication, while PSGAGs (e.g., Adequan) support cartilage matrix and may slow degradation. They are not cosmetic (B), osteophyte-destroying (C), or foal-only (D) agents.

questions.stem: Which intra-articular corticosteroids are commonly used and what is a key precaution?

options.label: A
options.text: Methylprednisolone and triamcinolone; strict aseptic technique and awareness that repeated use may accelerate cartilage degeneration

questions.explanation: Methylprednisolone acetate and triamcinolone acetate are commonly used; strict asepsis is essential, and repeated steroid use can soften cartilage and increase laminitis risk. Claims that no precautions are needed (B, C) or that corticosteroids are never used (D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: Which systemic or biologic therapies can be adjuncts in OA management?

options.label: A
options.text: Systemic HA/PSGAG courses and autologous biologics (IRAP, PRP, ACS) to modulate inflammation and cartilage breakdown

questions.explanation: Systemic HA/PSGAG and autologous biologics (IRAP, PRP, ACS) can reduce inflammatory mediators and help protect cartilage. Vitamins (B), antibiotics (C), and anthelmintics (D) do not specifically target OA pathophysiology.

questions.stem: Which precautions should be taken with repeated intra-articular corticosteroid use?

options.label: A
options.text: Use as frequently as possible to maintain comfort

options.label: B
options.text: Limit frequency to avoid cartilage softening and increased laminitis risk, and always use aseptic technique

options.label: D
options.text: Never reassess the joint after injection

questions.explanation: Corticosteroids should be used judiciously, balancing pain relief with the risk of cartilage damage and laminitis, and injections must be performed aseptically; monitoring for septic arthritis and “joint flares” is essential. Overuse (A) and lack of reassessment (D) are unsafe.

questions.stem: Which prognosis statement is MOST accurate for equine OA?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild OA in low-motion joints has a good prognosis with early management; severe OA in high-motion joints has a guarded to poor prognosis for athletic performance, though arthrodesis may restore comfort

options.label: B
options.text: All OA cases progress to complete ankylosis rapidly

options.label: C
options.text: OA has no impact on performance

options.label: D
options.text: Prognosis is always excellent regardless of severity

questions.explanation: Mild OA in low-motion joints often has a good prognosis with early, appropriate management, while severe OA in high-motion joints carries a guarded to poor prognosis for high-level performance; arthrodesis can restore comfort in some cases. Rapid ankylosis in all cases (B), no performance impact (C), or universally excellent prognosis (D) are not accurate.
